Review Conventional synthesis methods of short-chain dialkylcarbonates and novel production technology via direct route from alcohol and waste CO2 E. Leino a P. Mäki-Arvela a V. Eta a D. Yu. Murzin a ⁎ T. Salmi a J.-P. Mikkola a b a Laboratory of Industrial Chemistry and Reaction Engineering, Process Chemistry Centre, Åbo Akademi University, Biskopsgatan 8, 20500 Turku/Åbo, Finland b Department of Chemistry, Technical Chemistry, Chemical-Biological Center, Umeå University, SE-90187 Umeå, Sweden ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +358 2 215 4574; fax: +358 2 215 4479. Graphical abstract Research highlights ▶ Chemical fixation of carbon dioxide has been reviewed. ▶ Main focus on diethyl carbonate. ▶ Conventional technologies suffer from toxicity phosgene, corrosion and low production rate. ▶ Direct synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2 is thermodynamically unfeasible. ▶ Butylene oxide can be used as a chemical water trap. The aim of this work is to review different synthesis methods of dialkylcarbonates with special emphasis on diethyl carbonate synthesis methodologies. The novel synthesis route for dimethyl carbonate and diethyl carbonate based on the utilization of alcohol and carbon dioxide as the raw materials, together with heterogeneous catalysts, is presented. Keywords Dimethyl carbonate Diethyl carbonate Carbon dioxide Zirconia Palladium-copper chloride 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide next to water vapor, methane, nitrous oxide, freons, halocarbons and ozone is one of the most important and prominent greenhouse gases, which could result in a climate change by increasing solar warming of the earth's atmosphere. Combustion of fossil fuels, such as coal, oil and gas in power plants, emissions from transportation and industrial production, are the largest sources of CO2 emissions globally. The levels of carbon dioxide alone in the atmosphere have risen more than 30% since the Industrial Revolution in the 1700s. Continuous temperature increase on the Earth, caused by increasing levels of CO2 in the atmosphere might, consequently, result in melting of the arctic ice, increased forest fires, rising sea levels, expansion of deserts, loss of animal habitat, spreading of tropical diseases and more frequent and severe storms. Therefore, it is not surprising, that green processes based on chemical fixation of carbon dioxide have recently attracted much attention in industrial chemistry from the standpoint of the protection of environment. CO2 is recognized to be a cheap, recyclable and non-toxic carbon source that sometimes can replace toxic chemicals such as phosgene, isocyanates or carbon monoxide [1–4]. In addition, carbon dioxide is also an attractive C1 building block in organic synthesis producing useful organic compounds [5–7]. The industrial synthesis of urea, salicylic acid and methanol already involve carbon dioxide as a reactant. Recently, there has been much effort put on the development of new synthesis methods based on CO2 as a feedstock for organic carbonates due to their excellent properties and apparent commercial applications [8]. Another reason is that their production is historically dominated by extremely poisonous phosgene chemistry. Short-chain dialkylcarbonates such as dimethyl carbonate (DMC) or diethyl carbonate (DEC) are gaining popularity as replacements for hazardous chemical reagents or reactive solvents. Longer chain and branched dialkylcarbonates also find extensive use in lubricant, cosmetic, plasticizer, fuel and pharmaceutical compositions. The present interest towards the development of DMC synthesis methods and applications due to its versatility as a reagent and solvent and also its moderate toxicity for human health and environment is witnessed by a growth of literature and patents references, mainly in the most recent years [9,10]. In contrast, literature search on the preparation of DEC points out only a few patents and publications with an increase since the year 2000. Therefore, in this paper the special emphasis is put on DEC synthesis methodologies. Diethyl carbonate, the second homologue of dialkylcarbonate family is one of the most important green chemicals in carbonate esters also called ethyl carbonate, carbonic acid diethyl ester or Eufin. It is a colorless, transparent liquid under the normal conditions and has a mild toxicology profile [10]. Some properties of DEC are summarized in Table 1 . When released into the environment, DEC will slowly biodegrade to carbon dioxide and ethanol [11–13]—a fact rendering it a significant advantage over other fuel oxygenates such as methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE). DEC, by the presence of two ethyl groups and one carbonyl group in its structure, represents a viable alternative to both ethyl halides and phosgene for ethylation and carbonylation processes. Hence, it has lately attracted much interest in the chemical industry and in the motor fuel industry. Because of its high oxygen content (40.6wt%), diethyl carbonate has been proposed as a replacement for MTBE as an attractive oxygen-containing fuel additive. Moreover, gasoline/water distribution coefficients are more favorable for DEC when compared to dimethyl carbonate and ethanol [10]. DEC can also be used as a raw material for manufacturing of polycarbonates [14], and it is as an excellent solvent and an intermediate for various pharmaceuticals such as antibiotics and phenobarbital [15,16]. Furthermore, DEC is applied as a solvent of polyamide, polyacrylonitrile and diphenol resin in the synthetic fiber industry, as solvents of cellulose ether, synthetic and natural resin in the textile printing and dyeing industry and as a paint remover. It is worth to mention that DEC is widely used as an electrolyte in lithium ion batteries. The world-wide production and consumption of dialkylcarbonates is estimated to be several tens of thousands of tonnes per year, whereas the annual production capacity of DEC, at present, is estimated to be 6000mt/year industrial grade and 1200mt/year battery grade [17,18]. 2 Conventional diethyl carbonate production technologies 2.1 Phosgenation of ethanol The phosgene (COCl2)-ethanol process is the oldest method of producing DEC as has been reported by Muskat and Strain in 1941 [19]. Currently, the phosgenation is the most important industrial method for producing carbonic acid esters. It should be, however, mentioned that since the 1980s the oxidative carbonylation reaction has replaced the phosgenation as the main method of DMC synthesis (the EniChem and Ube process). Nevertheless, the application of this production technology for longer chain alcohols such as ethanol still faces several technical challenges. Therefore, DEC is manufactured almost exclusively by reacting ethanol with phosgene using technology developed in the 1940s [20]. The majority of the production processes for dialkylcarbonates follow a similar route, according to Eqs. (1) and (2) [21]. (1) ROH+COCl2 →ROC(O)Cl+HCl (2) ROC(O)Cl+ROH→(RO)2CO+HCl Phosgene reacts with an alcohol to form chloroformates which react further with another molecule of alcohol to form carbonate. The process occurs in anhydrous solvents such as toluene, dichloromethane or benzene with excess of pyridine, which act as a hydrochloric acid trap in order to shift the equilibrium of the reaction towards formation of dialkylcarbonates [19]. Pyridine is only one among many acid acceptors (dimethyl aniline, quaternary ammonium bases or inorganic bases such as oxides, hydroxides and carbonates) that may be used. The temperature of the reaction depends on the nature of the alkaline reagent. In the presence of pyridine or caustic soda, a temperature below room temperature is required in order to obtain higher yields of carbonic acid esters. On the other hand, when calcium carbonate is used, the reaction temperature should be above 50°C. Moreover, in the absence of base, the reaction requires high temperature to proceed (50–150°C) and results in poor carbonate yields. The main disadvantage of this method is the use of an extremely hazardous phosgene as a reactant. It decomposes in the lungs to form carbon monoxide and hydrochloric acid. Phosgene is classified by the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) as a class “A” poison. Therefore, in order to match the principles of “Green Chemistry” towards the lowest impact on human health and environment, there is an urgent need to develop alternative, more convenient and safe routes for those processes that are based on phosgene, its derivatives or the use of carbon monoxide. Synthesis methods for DEC via oxidative carbonylation of ethanol, reaction between ethyl nitrite (C2H5ONO) and carbon monoxide, reaction of ethanol with urea and direct synthesis method of DEC from ethanol and carbon dioxide are presented below. 2.2 Oxidative carbonylation of ethanol over a heterogeneous catalysts Until now, oxidative carbonylation of ethanol using heterogeneous catalysts is one of the most studied methods for producing DEC. Carbon monoxide and ethanol are the substrates for DEC synthesis that can be manufactured in huge quantities. The overall equation is: (3) 2C2H5OH+CO+(1/2)O2 →OC(OC2H5)2 +H2O 2.2.1 Oxidative carbonylation of ethanol over a CuCl2/PdCl2 supported on activated carbon Production of diethyl carbonate from ethanol and carbon monoxide in a homogeneous slurry of cuprous chloride (CuCl) catalyst resulted in significant amounts of DEC. However, this only occurred when an extreme excess of CO was employed [22]. DMC synthesis by oxidative carbonylation of methanol over the heterogeneous Pd-Cu bimetallic chloride catalysts supported on activated carbon seems more profitable than the method using the single metal chloride catalysts [23]. In fact, reasonably low temperatures (<200°C) and pressures (<20atm) are sufficient. The same catalytic system was investigated later altering, however, the catalyst composition in order to maximize the amount of DEC produced and to gain insight into the active forms of the supported metal species [11]. The synthesis was carried out in gas phase, which is more attractive due to avoiding the drawbacks of the liquid-phase process, such as halide induced corrosion and difficulties in separating the catalyst from the product. Numerous different solid supported catalysts prepared from copper and/or palladium salts were employed. It has been observed, that the substitution of acetate for chloride has led to a decreased production of DEC and to increased production of undesired by-products. Consequently, this indicates that the chloride ion is an important component in the catalyst and, thus, exhibits an important role in the production of DEC. In accordance with the research conducted on the oxidative carbonylation of methanol [24] the inclusion of palladium(II) chloride, along with copper(II) chloride, enhanced the production of DEC when supported on activated carbon (AC). Further, it has been shown that alumina and silica-supported catalysts performed much worse in comparison to activated carbon, concluding, that the nature of the support has a strong influence on the reaction. Based on the previous studies resulting in increased yields of DMC, when a metal hydroxide was added to the copper-palladium catalyst [25], it has been confirmed that the CuCl2/PdCl2/activated carbon catalyst treated with metal hydroxide salts, particularly with potassium hydroxide, almost duplicated the production of DEC without increasing the amounts of by-products formed. No data on ethanol conversion and selectivity of ethanol to DEC were given in reference [11]. 2.2.1.1 The impact of potassium on the synthesis of diethyl carbonate The effect of various potassium salts (potassium acetate, potassium citrate tribasic monohydrate, potassium sorbic, potassium chloride) in CuCl2/PdCl2/activated carbon catalyst using a continuous reactor system was studied in order to enhance the transformation rate of reactants and the yield of DEC [26]. When potassium chloride (KCl) was added as a promoter in the catalyst CuCl2/PdCl2/NaOH/activated carbon, the reaction exhibited the best catalytic activity (Fig. 1 ). This is consistent with the previously reported research conducted on the oxidative carbonylation of methanol [27]. The formation of by-products is independent of the main reaction of DEC synthesis and a four-step mechanism for the formation of the by-products was proposed as follows: (4) C2H5OH+(1/2)O2 →CH3CHO+H2O (5) CH3CHO+(1/2)O2 →CH3COOH (6) CH3COOH+C2H5OH→CH3COOC2H5 (7) CH3CHO+2C2H5OH→C2H5O(CH)(CH3)OC2H5 +H2O The comparison of CuCl2/PdCl2/NaOH/activated carbon catalyst with CuCl2/PdCl2/NaOH/KCl/activated carbon has shown that the catalytic activity remained steady within 30h after adding KCl on the catalysts, while the catalyst without potassium chloride deactivated after 6h. The selectivity to DEC did not increase after addition of KCl, indicating that potassium chloride can improve the catalytic activity without enhancing the selectivity to diethyl carbonate (Fig. 2 ). Chlorine leaching was observed in CuCl2/PdCl2/NaOH/activated carbon catalyst, since its content decreased from 12.6% to 6.5% during the reaction. Leaching was confirmed by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). This result indicated the importance of the chloride ion in the catalysts for DEC formation. The leaching of chloride ion is the main reason of the deactivation of the catalyst and, therefore, fixation of the chloride ion plays a key role in prolonging the lifetime of the catalyst. Another study focused on the evaluation of the catalytic activity of KCl promoted CuCl2/PdCl2/NaOH/activated carbon catalysts [28]. The conversion of ethanol and the yield of DEC distinctly increased without any change in the selectivity at the same space velocity (Fig. 3 ), when the oxygen/ethanol molar ratio was increased from 1:8 to 1:4. The conversion of ethanol exceeded 30%, while catalysts with other potassium promoters showed only an insignificant variation in their catalytic performance, at the same space velocity when the molar ratio oxygen/ethanol increased. Furthermore, the effect of the reactant feed ratio on the conversion of ethanol, selectivity of ethanol to DEC, selectivity of oxygen to DEC, and selectivity of CO to DEC were investigated on a CuCl2/PdCl2/KCl/NaOH/activated carbon catalyst. Conversion of ethanol and the selectivity for CO to DEC increased significantly in the range of 4–10ml O2/min. This indicates that there is a great influence of the flow rate of oxygen on the performance of the CuCl2/PdCl2/KCl/NaOH/activated carbon catalyst. The conversion of ethanol reached a maximum when the flow rate of oxygen was increased to the stoichiometric ratio (based on ethanol), beyond which CO was more easily oxidized to CO2 and ethanol to the other by-products. It was found that the optimal molar O2-to-C2H5OH ratio lies around 0.25. Additionally, the best molar ratio for CO, O2 and C2H5OH was proposed to be 10:1:4. The reaction mechanism of the oxidative carbonylation of ethanol over the CuCl2/PdCl2/KCl/NaOH/AC catalyst proposed by Zhang et al. [28] presumes that PdCl2 species interact with an active copper phase Cu(OH)Cl through a chlorine atom and a hydroxyl group. Subsequently, the coordinated chlorine might be substituted by carbon monoxide and ethoxy group as a result of CO and C2H5OH attack on palladium chloride, together with the production of hydrochloric acid. Furthermore, previous studies suggested that a carbonyl ligand might be incorporated into palladium, based on the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analysis [29]. The production of DEC from carbonyl and oxyethyl ligands coordinated to palladium induces the reduction of the Pd2+ into metallic palladium, which further can be easily re-oxidized by Cu(OH)Cl. The electron transfer between Cu2+ and metallic palladium as an “outer-sphere” mechanism has been considered since no change in the intermediates was observed. This process, so-called electron rearrangement process, follows the Frank–Condon rule [30]. In these reactions there is no time for the geometry to change in the intermediate complex [31,32]. The last step consisted in the re-oxidation of Cu+ compound into Cu(OH)Cl by oxygen. 2.2.1.2 The gas phase DEC synthesis using a laboratory-scale pulse-quench-flow reactor Previous studies conducted by Dunn et al. [11] in a batch reactor indicated an improvement in the yield of DEC when the CuCl2/PdCl2/activated carbon catalyst was treated with KOH after loading of the support with the chloride salts. This post-treatment created an additional phase of copper, atacamite, which resulted in the formation of a more active catalyst [33]. The pulse-quench-flow reactor (Fig. 4 ) was used for DEC synthesis by oxidative carbonylation of ethanol in gas phase over the most active catalyst according to the results obtained in the batch reactor experiments, i.e. CuCl2/PdCl2/activated carbon-KOH [34]. The continuous flow reactor setup allows for simple regulation of the residence time by modifying the flow rate of the N2 carrier gas. A clear increase in the conversion of ethanol into DEC was achieved with increasing residence time, while the selectivity for DEC remained constant at 100%. Moreover, the variation in total system pressure affects the partial pressures of the reactants. This should affect the yield of products by influencing the reaction kinetics. Furthermore, by increasing the total pressure, the gaseous reactants are compressed. This, in turn, resulted in prolonged residence times. It has been observed that an increased pressure clearly affected the synthesis of DEC. At atmospheric pressure only trace amounts of DEC were formed, while its production increased from 6% to 11% with an increase in the operational pressure from 0.17 to 1.03MPa. The effect of reaction temperature on DEC production was investigated. Two shortest residence times have shown to have very minor temperature dependence in comparison to the three longer residence times. Presumably, the reason was a too short contact time with the catalyst (Fig. 5 ). The yield of DEC appeared to decrease as a function of temperature between 150 and 180°C which was probably caused by an enhanced catalyst deactivation at high temperatures as well as by an increased reactant mass throughput compared to lower temperatures. By-product formation is also an important topic in any synthesis. Appreciable amounts of by-products, such as diethoxymethane (DEM), acetaldehyde (Ace), and ethyl formate (EtFOR) were formed during batch reactor experiments [11]. When ethanol was introduced into the flow reactor in a stoichiometric excess, only DEM among the various observed by-products of DEC synthesis could be detected (Fig. 6 ). In the region when ethanol was the limiting reactant, a decrease in the DEC yield with increasing flow rate of ethanol could be observed. The DEC yield was nearly constant in the region characterized by the molar ratio of ethanol being in excess of 1.0, indicating that when more ethanol was introduced, larger portion of it remained unreacted. The amount of DEM increased independently of the amount of DEC. This means, that the reaction which produced DEM must be independent of DEC formation, and thus the reaction mechanism is not a sequential one. Next, it was studied how the treatment of CuCl2/PdCl2/activated carbon catalyst with various metal hydroxides influenced the space time yield of DEC and DEM. Metal hydroxides undoubtedly enhanced DEC production although DEC selectivity did not decrease. Potassium hydroxide, among the other metal hydroxides, again exhibited the best catalytic performance. Furthermore, the amount of by-product DEM was diminished almost by half when KOH was added to CuCl2/PdCl2/activated carbon catalyst. Interestingly, Mg(OH)2 as the source of hydroxide markedly improved the catalytic performance in DEC synthesis. 2.2.2 Oxidative carbonylation of ethanol over a PdCl2/Cu supported on hexagonal mesoporous silica It is well known that the nature of the support has an important function in the structure and activity of supported catalysts. Up till now, only activated carbons have been widely used as supports for DEC synthesis via oxidative carbonylation. Therefore, much interest has been devoted to develop more suitable supports other than active carbon for more efficient gas phase oxidative carbonylation of ethanol to DEC. Hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) materials are claimed to have larger pores, to be more stable and have thicker pore walls than their MCM-41 counterparts [35]. Cu-substituted HMS as catalysts for DEC synthesis were first studied in the year 2007 by Zhang et al. [36]. No conversion of ethanol to DEC was observed over pure Cu-HMS and over PdCl2/HMS catalysts, while PdCl2/Cu-HMS exhibited excellent catalytic performance. The comparison of the two catalyst systems, namely PdCl2/Cu-HMS and PdCl2-CuCl2/HMS is shown in Table 2 . The reaction mechanism for the synthesis of DEC over the PdCl2/Cu-HMS catalytic system was proposed (Fig. 7 ) [36]. It is well known that in a Wacker-type redox system composed of Pd and Cu, the Cu–Pd couple bridged by chlorine and hydroxyl ligands showed considerable reactivity for the redox process of Cu2+/Cu+ and Pd2+/Pd0, at the same time [28]. It was suggested that Si–O–Cu groups as a unit of Cu-HMS, interacted with impregnated Pd2+ species. Consequently, this could facilitate an efficient electron transfer during reaction progress. The Si–O–Cu group is attacked by Pd species loaded on the surface of Cu-HMS or pore channel. Subsequently, the chlorine atom contained in the intermediate might be substituted by carbon monoxide and ethoxy group as a result of CO and C2H5OH introduction into the pore channel of the catalysts. In the synthesis of a DEC molecule, the electron transfer between Cu2+/Cu+ and Pd2+/Pd0 is considered to be necessary. Finally, re-oxidation of Cu+ species into Si–O–Cu groups is completed by the reactant O2. The formation of an active catalytic centre for Si–O–Cu species could be crucial for the synthesis of DEC. Therefore, the PdCl2-CuCl2/HMS catalysts, for which Pd and Cu are irregularly supported and dispersed on silica showed low activity in the gas phase operation, while for the PdCl2/Cu-HMS catalysts the probability of Cu and Pd interaction is much higher. Textural structures of silica can be modified by an introduction of quaternary ammonium salts (QAS) as a surfactant [37]. Therefore, the effect of the addition of various quaternary ammonium salts such as cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), cetyltrimethylammonium chloride (CTAC) and tetraethylammonium bromide (TEAB) on the catalytic activity of PdCl2-CuCl2 catalysts supported on HMS was investigated [38]. It was observed that QAS improved the catalytic performance of PdCl2-CuCl2/HMS catalyst (Fig. 8 ), whereas PdCl2-CuCl2-TEAB-HMS proved to be the best catalyst. The influence of TEAB as a surfactant for silica has been investigated in detail. The catalytic performance of PdCl2-CuCl2/HMS catalysts has been examined by changing the molar ratios of TEAB/Pd. At a low TEAB/Pd mole ratio, DEC formation gradually increased. Consequently, for TEAB-to-Pd ratios higher from 12:1, it appeared to decrease. Ethanol conversion followed the same trend as the space time yield of DEC and the selectivity based on ethanol to DEC remained over 90%. Therefore, it has been suggested that an optimum TEAB-to-Pd mole ratio should be around 12:1. 2.3 Carbonylation of ethyl nitrite over supported palladium catalysts Instead of oxidative carbonylation of ethanol, another method to produce DEC has been developed: the procedure uses ethyl nitrite as a substitute for ethanol and oxygen. This synthesis procedure is similar to the synthesis of diethyl oxalate (DEO), in which DEC is generated as a by-product [39] and two consecutive reactions are involved. First, ethanol is converted into ethyl nitrite (Eq. (8)) and, subsequently, into DEC via reaction with carbon monoxide (Eq. (9)). This is the same overall reaction as described in Eq. (3). It should, however, be pointed out that the carbonylation of ethyl nitrite is not environmentally friendly due to the formation of nitrogen monoxide. (8) 2C2H5OH+2NO+(1/2)O2 →2C2H5ONO+H2O (9) CO+2C2H5ONO→OC(OC2H5)2 +2NO In this synthesis method ethyl nitrite plays a dual role, i.e. it acts as a substrate for DEC formation and as an oxidant to maintain the activity of palladium catalyst [40]. Therefore, the introduction of another oxidant, such as oxygen into the reaction system is not necessary. 2.3.1 Carbonylation of ethyl nitrite over palladium catalysts supported on mesoporous MCM-41 In contrast to DEC, many examples of DMC synthesis methods from carbon monoxide and methyl nitrite have been provided [41–44]. For DEC synthesis (the reaction between carbon monoxide and ethyl nitrite), palladium catalysts supported on mobile crystalline material (MCM-41) has been reported for the first time by Jiang et al. in 2000 [45]. MCM-41 type mesoporous molecular sieves possessing a hexagonal array of uniform mesopores have attracted an attention due to their elevated specific surface area, high thermal and hydrothermal stability, possibility to control their pore size, hydrophobicity as well as acidity. These features render MCM-41 a promising material as a catalyst and/or a support. Other uses comprise industrial applications such as adsorption processes [46], ion exchange [47] and environmental control [48]. In order to explore effective catalysts for DEC production (reaction between carbon monoxide and ethyl nitrite), Si-MCM-41 and Ti-MCM-41 mesoporous molecular sieves have been utilized as the supports for palladium [45]. It has been observed that the catalytic behavior of the catalysts relied on a specific property of the support. The catalysts Pd, Pd-Cu and Pd-Ti doped on Si-MCM-41 demonstrated higher catalytic activities than the catalysts supported on Ti-MCM-41. An interesting observation was that the catalyst 1.5wt% Pd-0.5wt% Ti/Si-MCM-41 was favorable for DEC synthesis, while for the catalyst 1.5wt% Pd-0.5wt% Cu/Ti-MCM-41, DEO was the dominant product. Furthermore, two catalysts, 1.5wt% Pd/Si-MCM-41 and 1.5wt% Pd 0.5wt% Cu/Si-MCM-41, favored DEO formation, whereas 1.5wt% Pd/Ti-MCM-41 and 1.5wt% Pd-0.5wt% Cu/Ti-MCM-41 favored DEC at a temperature range of 80–110°C. This indicates that the isomorphous substitution of Si by Ti in the MCM-41 support seems to favor DEC formation from carbon monoxide and ethyl nitrite. 2.3.2 Carbonylation of ethyl nitrite over carbon-supported palladium catalyst system The effect of various carries such as SiO2, α-Al2O3, HMS and activated carbon for Wacker-type catalysts has been proven. PdCl2-CuCl2 supported on activated carbon was the most efficient catalyst for DEC synthesis from carbon monoxide and ethyl nitrite [49]. Therefore, palladium catalysts supported on activated carbon have been employed in highly active catalysts for DEC synthesis by carbonylation of ethyl nitrite [12]. It was found that PdCl2/activated carbon catalyst showed “poor” catalytic activity by comparison to other binary catalyst systems (Table 3 ). PdCl2-FeCl3/activated carbon and PdCl2-BiCl3/activated carbon catalysts displayed a good DEC selectivity. However, the conversion of CO was much lower comparing to that achieved by PdCl2-CuCl2/activated carbon. One of the possible explanations of the working mechanism for these catalysts is that they work as promoters for Pd redox cycle in a somewhat similar way as the well known CO oxidation Wacker process over a PdCl2–CuCl2 catalyst (Fig. 9 ). The initial Pd2+ species are reduced to Pd0 by carbon monoxide and subsequently re-oxidized to Pd2+ species by a Cu2+ compound (reduced during this process into Cu+). It is believed that in this process Pd2+ performs better than other palladium species for DEC production. In the range of 100–130°C the effect of the reaction temperature on DEC yield over PdCl2-CuCl2/activated carbon catalyst was studied [12]. Only traces of DEC were formed at room temperature, while an increase in temperature resulted in higher productivity of DEC. Nevertheless, when the reaction temperature was above 120°C, the space time yield of DEC decreased due to the decomposition of ethyl nitrite, which on the other hand occurs at 116°C under normal pressure [40]. Additionally, the effect of treating the activated carbon-supported PdCl2-CuCl2 catalyst with different additives has been investigated [12]. The additives such as CeCl3, PrCl3, LaCl3 enhanced the DEC formation, while others, i.e. CH3COOK, BiCl3, and (NH4)6Mo7O24 did not exhibit any effect. It is worth to mention that PdCl2-CuCl2-(NH4)6Mo7O24/activated carbon catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity for DMC production starting from CO and CH3ONO [42]. For all these modified catalysts, DEO was detected as the principal by-product and this, in turn, directly affected the selectivity towards DEC. Thus, it can be concluded that certain additives enhance the production of DEC and also increase the DEC selectivity by retarding the by-product formation. During DEC synthesis, the activity of PdCl2-CuCl2 catalyst supported on activated carbon declined due to the loss of surface chlorine [27]. Production of ethyl chloroformate as one of the by-products occur, presumably, through formation of palladium ethoxycarbonyl chloride PdCl x (OC2H5)(NO) as the reaction intermediate [40]. The release of ethyl chloroformate causes the reduction of Pd species and progressive catalyst deactivation during the reaction. The following hypothetical mechanism for the catalyst deactivation can be elucidated: (10) PdCl2 +C2H5ONO→PdCl x (OC2H5)(NO) (11) PdCl x (OC2H5)(NO)+CO→PdCl x (COOC2H5)(NO) (12) PdCl x (COOC2H5)(NO)→Pd0 +ClCOOC2H5 +NO It has also been observed that the pretreatment of activated carbon positively affects the catalytic activity of PdCl2-CuCl2/activated carbon catalyst (Table 4 ) [49]. The conversion of CO and space time yield of DEC over PdCl2-CuCl2/activated carbon catalyst pretreated with H2 catalyst (Table 4, C-4) is much higher compared to the three other counterparts. This demonstrates how the catalytic performance depends on the surface pretreatment method of the carbon carries for the carbon-supported Wacker-type catalysts. Pd content played an important role in the DEC synthesis from carbon monoxide and ethyl nitrite. Considering both DEC production and selectivity, it can be stated that the optimal Pd content appears to be around 2wt% and the optimum Pd/Cu mole ratio around 0.5. 2.4 Catalytic alcoholysis of urea Synthesis of urea has been a traditional industrial process for carbon dioxide utilization. As a CO2 carrier, urea is cheap and widely available and, therefore, it was thought to be a potential route for the synthesis of important organic compounds, such as short-chain dialkyl carbonates. There are several advantages of this process, i.e. abundant resources, low cost of raw materials, no azeotrope formation between alcohol and water as well as easy product separation and purification. Dialkylcarbonate is prepared by reacting an aliphatic alcohol with urea in the presence of various catalysts (Eq. (13)). In this process, urea plays a role as a carbonylation agent. Furthermore, the co-product ammonia can be recycled to urea (Eq. (14)) [50]. (13) NH2CONH2 +2C2H5OH⇌2(C2H5O)2CO+2NH3 (14) 2NH3 +CO2 ⇌NH2CONH2 +H2O Although this process is an interesting route, there exist only few reports about it. The synthesis of DMC from urea and methanol using organotin compounds and simple basic catalysts such as K2CO3, CH3ONa, CaO, MgO has been reported. The DMC yield was, however, very low [51–54]. The homogeneous nature of the organotin brings along separation and deactivation problems. Additionally, the toxicity of organotin compounds is also a disadvantage in industrial applications. Palladium, zinc and some alkali metal compounds could be used as catalysts for carbonates production from urea and aliphatic alcohol, as well [55,56]. Zinc oxide (ZnO), calcium oxide (CaO), lead oxide (PdO), zirconium dioxide (ZrO2), titanium dioxide (TiO2), tin dioxide (SnO2), magnesium oxide (MgO) and γ-aluminum oxide (γ-Al2O3) have been employed as catalysts for DEC synthesis from urea [57]. The comparison of these catalysts is tabulated in Table 5 . Among various catalysts, ZnO exhibited the best catalytic performance (Entry 2). ZrO2 also showed high activity towards DEC while γ-Al2O3 was the least active catalyst, probably due to its stronger acidity compared to CaO or MgO. It was proposed that high activity of ZnO and ZrO2 is attributed to their acidic and basic properties [58]. The reaction without catalyst (Entry 1) resulted in 84% yield of ethyl carbamate (EC) and no DEC generation, indicating that EC was the intermediate for DEC formation from urea and ethanol. The following two-step reaction mechanism for DEC synthesis from urea and ethanol via ethyl carbamate intermediate has been proposed: (15) NH2CONH2 +C2H5OH⇌NH2COOC2H5 +NH3 (16) NH2COOC2H5 +C2H5OH⇌C2H5OCOOC2H5 +NH3 Thermodynamic calculations revealed that the changes in Gibbs free energy for reactions (15) and (16) are 0.66 and 20.09kJ/mol, respectively, at standard state. This indicated that reactions cannot occur spontaneously under these conditions and the change in Gibbs free energy for the reaction (16) is larger than that for reaction (15). Thus, the target product DEC is much more difficult to synthesize than the intermediate product EC. DEC yield increased with prolonged reaction time and reached a maximum after 5h, followed by a gradual decline in yield. Thus, the rate of DEC production is lower than that of consumption by side reactions after 5h. Therefore, the optimum reaction time for DEC synthesis via the urea route seems to be around 5h. Biuret, N-ethyl ethyl carbamate and N-ethyl urea formed in the reactions (18)–(20), respectively, have been observed as by-products and the mechanism of their formation have been proposed as follows: (17) N H 2 CON H 2 ⟶ Δ HNCO + N H 3 (18) HNCO+NH2CONH2 ⇌NH2CONHCONH2 (19) C2H5OOCOC2H5 +C2H5OCONH2 ⇌C2H5OCONHC2H5 +C2H5OH+CO2 (20) C2H5OOCOC2H5 +NH2CONH2 ⇌NH2CONHC2H5 +C2H5OH+CO2 It has also been shown that DEC yield increased with increase in catalyst loading, as expected. However, when the catalyst amount was 6wt%, DEC yield started to decrease, presumably due to larger consumption of DEC by side reactions. Consequently, metal oxides, such as Zn, Pb or Sn, might also catalyze the ethylization reaction of DEC and accelerate reaction (19), thus decreasing the selectivity towards DEC [59]. It is worth to note, that catalytic distillation technology effectively increased the yield of DMC from urea and methanol. The DMC yield reached about 70%, which was almost a two-fold increase when compared to the batch process [60,61]. 3 Novel technology for synthesis of short-chain dialkylcarbonates Undoubtedly, natural green plant photosynthesis is the most important chemical reaction on the Earth and the basis for all life processes. However, this natural phenomenon that controls the world temperature is disturbed by continuous increase in the amount of greenhouse gases (in particular CO2) over the years. The idea that anthropogenic carbon dioxide due to its long atmospheric lifetime [62] may affect the climate change of the Earth for hundreds of thousands of years reaches more and more public awareness and focuses attention on CO2 capture and utilization. Methods for carbon dioxide capture and storage which allow CO2 to be separated, liquefied and stored on a large scale are being nowadays developed and tested by many energy companies world-wide. Several conventional technologies are proposed for CO2 capture and sequestration, such as mineral carbonation [63], absorption in amine solutions [64], CO2 sequestration in deep saline aquifers and coal beds [65]. Another way which could contribute to complete (balance) global CO2 cycle is the chemical fixation of CO2 to useful and value-added chemicals. Furthermore, it would allow CO2 to be viewed as a valuable renewable feedstock. It should be, however, pointed out that synthesis of chemicals using carbon dioxide as a raw material is still an under-developed area due to the fact that CO2 is highly thermodynamically stable and kinetically inert. The problem of CO2 activation is a continuous challenge for the synthetic chemists to “force” this molecule into selective reactions under mild enough conditions. The conversion of CO2 into fuels and polymeric/construction materials is at present in significant demand [66], including the conversion of CO2 to methanol [67], formic acid [68], methyl formate [69] and higher hydrocarbons [70] which all are of great interest. Concurrently, the direct synthesis of dialkylcarbonate from CO2 and an alcohol (Eq. (21)) is an attractive approach for the chemical carbon dioxide fixation and is presently regarded as a green chemical process. (21) 2CH3OH+CO2 ⇌(CH3O)2CO+H2O In contrast to DEC, the straightforward reaction of methanol and CO2 leading to DMC has been studied intensively over a wide range of catalysts, such as organometallic compounds [71–74], metal tetra-alkoxides [75], potassium carbonate [76], Ni(CH3COO)2 [77], zirconia [78–80], CeO2 [81,82], CeO2-ZrO2 [83,84], H3PW12O40/ZrO2 [85], H3PO4-ZrO4 [86,87], H3PO4-V2O5 [88] and Cu-Ni/VSO [89]. In spite of considerable efforts devoted to producing DMC via a direct route the catalytic performance is still far from satisfactory. Catalyst deactivation and hydrolysis of DMC caused by co-produced water (Eq. (21)) are postulated as the reason for the low productivity. Further, the thermodynamics of DMC formation is not favorable since the reaction does not occur spontaneously even at ambient conditions. The current chapter of this review will focus more on the results of direct synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2 obtained by our research group. In addition, the detailed thermodynamic calculations for direct reaction route of DMC formation are given below. 3.1 Direct synthesis method of dimethyl carbonate from methanol and CO2 over heterogeneous zirconia catalysts Currently, DMC is mainly prepared in industry by the oxidative carbonylation of methanol, which was initially developed by Enichem in Italy in 1980s. Nevertheless, this method suffers from low production rate, the need for corrosion resistant reactors and toxicity issues. Therefore, direct synthesis of DMC from carbon dioxide and methanol is obviously more attractive from practical and from environmental point of view due to the use of waste CO2. Dimethyl carbonate has been synthesized over homogenous di-methoxide catalysts from dehydrated methanol derivatives such as ortho-esters [90] and acetals [91,72] at 30MPa and 180°C. However, disadvantages of this method, such as the high cost of the starting materials and the difficulties in catalyst–product separation were reasons for further studies employing solid heterogeneous catalysts. Among the various tested catalysts, ZrO2 has been found to be the most active. The effectiveness of this catalyst was attributed to the presence of both acidic and basic sites. It has been proposed that basic sites are required to activate methanol and carbon dioxide, whereas acidic sites are required to supply methyl groups from methanol in the final step of the reaction. 3.1.1 Synthesis of dimethyl carbonate without water elimination The amounts of DMC obtained from the reaction between methanol and CO2 over different zirconia catalysts remained very low (Table 6 ), likely due to the rapidly reached unfavorable equilibrium state [92]. It has also been observed that no DMC was produced in the absence of a catalyst under the same conditions, while a two-fold increase in the amount of catalyst did not change DMC yield significantly (Entries 3 and 4). Therefore, the reaction might be limited by thermodynamics. The amount of DMC was affected by several parameters, i.e. by the calcination temperature of the catalyst, by the reaction time, temperature and pressure, respectively. An increase in the calcination temperature resulted in an increase in the amount of DMC formed, probably because, at higher temperatures, the stable monoclinic ZrO2 can reconfigure to a more active tetragonal phase. Further, the reaction levelled off after 6h reaction time, suggesting that the reaction equilibrium was established. Above a temperature of 160°C, the amount of DMC decreased at constant pressure and, therefore, the reaction temperature should be kept below 160°C. An increase in the pressure, at a relatively low temperature (170°C), improved the DMC yield, but the amount produced was less than 0.5mmol, at 20MPa. 3.1.2 Synthesis of dimethyl carbonate with water elimination using butylene oxide as a chemical water trap Despite the high selectivity in DMC synthesis from methanol and CO2 over a ZrO2 catalyst described above, the amount of DMC produced remains very low. The plausible drawbacks are thermodynamic limitations and hydrolysis of DMC caused by co-produced water (Eq. (21)). Presence of water easily shifts the equilibrium towards the reactants. Physical methods for water elimination, such as use of many kinds of drying agents including molecular sieves [93], 2,2-dimethoxy propane [84] and CaCl2 [94] have been studied, but their performance remained negligible for reactions performed at high temperature and pressure. Another, more attractive method for water removal is the use of higher epoxides as dehydrating agents, e.g. ethylene or propylene oxide. The one-pot reaction (Fig. 10a) leads to multiple products and to a low DMC selectivity due to alcoholysis and cyclization of the epoxide. Ethylene or propylene oxide reacts with carbon dioxide to form cyclic carbonate, which after separation undergoes transesterification with methanol to yield DMC and the corresponding glycol as depicted in Fig. 10b. It is well known that the transesterification of propylene carbonate with methanol to form DMC is recently used in the industrial synthesis process [95,96]. In this system, the formation of glycol as a by-product is unavoidable. Several papers exist of glycol recycling via reaction with carbon dioxide to form carbonate, which can successively be reused for the production of corresponding dialkylcarbonate (Fig. 10c) [95,97–100]. Series of organic bases, such as triethylamine (TEA), 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) and 1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0]dec-5-ene (TBD) have been employed for the synthesis of propylene carbonate (PC) from propylene glycol (PG) and CO2 in the presence of acetonitrile [95]. The yield of PC reached 15.3% with the selectivity of 100% with TBD under the optimal conditions. In addition, CeO2-ZrO2 has been developed by Tomishige et al. as an active catalyst for the synthesis of propylene carbonate or ethylene carbonate from the suitable glycol and CO2 in supercritical conditions [98]. Straightforward synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2 involving butylene oxide as an effective and recyclable chemical water trap over various catalysts has been investigated. The aim was to shift equilibrium and to achieve higher yields of DMC. The following reaction mechanism was proposed (Fig. 11 ) [92]. The advantage of this method is that butylene oxide was used as the dehydrating agent. Butylene oxide use implies lower health hazards and higher reactivity towards alcohols and CO2, compared to ethylene or propylene oxide. In comparison to the synthetic method in the absence of water elimination, a five-fold enhancement in the amount of DMC was obtained in the presence of butylene oxide (Table 7 , ZrO2 catalyst). The conversion of butylene oxide was about 98%, at 170°C and 10MPa, respectively. The by-products, such as 1-methoxy-2-butanol as well as intermediates (i.e. butylene carbonate), were selectively inhibited or converted by selecting appropriate catalysts and suitable reaction conditions. Consequently, high productivity in DMC synthesis was achieved, indicating that the equilibrium of the reaction was shifted towards products. 3.1.3 Thermodynamic limitations in the direct synthesis of DMC from methanol and carbon dioxide It is well known that thermodynamics as an intrinsic and fundamental characteristic for the reaction system is a crucial factor for the occurrence of a chemical reaction and the formation of the target product, in highest yields. Therefore, understanding the thermodynamics of DMC formation using methanol and carbon dioxide as feedstocks is highly important in seeking novel synthesis ideas, in academic investigations and in practical applications. The thermodynamic data of various substances such as methanol, carbon dioxide, DMC and water involved in reaction (21) are listed in Table 8 . Hence, the enthalpy and Gibbs energy of the reaction at 298K were estimated from the Δ G f θ and Δ H f θ values: (22) Δ r H 298 K θ = − 27.90 kJ / mol (23) Δ r G 298 K θ = 26.21 kJ / mol Based on the obtained values it can be concluded that the reaction is exothermic ( Δ r H 298 K θ = − 27.90 kJ / mol < 0 ) and it does not occur spontaneously at room temperature due to Δ r G 298 K θ = 26.21 kJ / mol > 0 . The relative pattern of the reaction heat with the temperature is expressed by the Kirchhoff's law (Eq. (24)), which shows that the reaction heat becomes more negative when the temperature increases. (24) Δ H r θ = Δ r H 298 K θ + Δ C p ( T − 298 ) = − 23.29 − 0.0155 T for ΔC p : Δ C p = ( 109.50 + 75.30 ) − ( 2 x 81.59 + 37.10 ) = − 15.48 J / mol = − 0.0155 kJ / mol Gibbs energy of the reaction at different temperatures can be expressed by Gibbs–Helmholtz equation (Eq. (25)), which can be transformed to Eq. (26) showing that the value of Δ G f θ increases with the reaction temperature. For instance, when the reaction temperature reaches 80°C (353K), Δ G 353 K θ is equal to 36.31kJ/mol and also from the thermodynamics point of view, an increase of the temperature is a disadvantage in DMC synthesis. (25) d Δ r G θ T = 23.29 + 0.0155 T T 2 d T (26) Δ r G T θ = T Δ r G 298 K θ 298 − 23.29 1 T − 1 298 T + 0.0155 T ln T 298 In accordance with the Gibbs free energy equation dG = V dP − S dT, Gibbs free energy change can be expressed as d(ΔG)=(ΔV)dP −(ΔS)dT. Considering CO2 as an ideal gas, the Gibbs energy of reaction as a function of pressure at constant temperature can be written as follows: (27) d Δ r G = Δ V d P = V 1 − V g d P = − V g d P = − R T P d P (28) Δ r G P = Δ r G θ − R T ln P P θ Calculations on the basis of Eq. (28) showed that when P ≥2.41×104 MPa, the Gibbs energy of the reaction is Δ r G p ≤0. This indicates that the reaction transforms to a spontaneous one at 80°C when the pressure of the reaction system exceeds 2.41×104 MPa. However, such an enormous pressure is not technically feasible. In other words, this synthesis reaction cannot occur under conventional industrial conditions and consequently some chemical or physical measures should be taken to shift the equilibrium in favor of the products. An analogous calculation has been conducted for the direct synthesis of DEC from ethanol and carbon dioxide and it was proven that the reaction is not thermodynamically feasible [102]. However, when ethylene or propylene oxide has been introduced into the reaction media as a water trap, the synthesis of DEC from carbon dioxide and ethanol becomes practical. 3.2 Current attempts towards DEC synthesis via direct route over heterogeneous catalysts As mentioned above, the synthesis of DEC from ethanol and CO2 has not been under intensive study so far. Thus, in this review, much effort has been put in order to find all currently available reports in the open literature on this topic. In 2002, for the first time Tomishige et al. reported that CeO2 −ZrO2 (Ce/(Ce+Zr)=0.2) solid solution exhibits catalytic activity in the selective formation of DEC from ethanol and CO2, at 110°C and 6MPa [84]. The expected by-products for this reaction are ethylene (Eq. (29)) and diethyl ether (Eq. (30)). However, the concentrations for both of them were below the detection limit. (29) C2H5OH→C2H4 +H2O (30) 2C2H5OH→C2H5OC2H5 +H2O The dependence of DEC yield on reaction time and catalyst weight has been observed. When either 0.1, 0.5 or 1.4g of CeO2 −ZrO2 (Ce/(Ce+Zr)=0.2) catalyst was employed, DEC yield was almost the same (0.4mmol) after an appropriate reaction time. Therefore, it is likely that this level corresponds to the equilibrium level of DEC formation from ethanol and carbon dioxide. Moreover, when comparing DMC or DEC formation by direct synthesis method (from methanol or ethanol and carbon dioxide) over a CeO2 catalyst, at a low reaction temperature, it was observed that the amount of carbonates increased with increasing catalyst amount, whereas at 170°C equal amounts of carbonates were obtained independent on the catalyst amount, indicating that the equilibrium was achieved [103]. More accurate studies on direct synthesis of DEC over Ce x Zr1−x O2 have been reported by Wang et al. [104,105]. It has been shown that Ce x Zr1−x O2 (x =1) demonstrated the highest activity towards DEC followed by Ce x Zr1−x O2 (x =0.7). The reason of that was a strong dependence of catalytic properties of Ce x Zr1−x O2 on the crystal structures and the acid–base sites on the surface with varied Ce/Zr ratios, discussed in detail in [105]. Furthermore, the DEC yield increased with increasing the calcination temperature up to 800°C followed by a decrease in DEC yield at higher calcination temperatures. Also, an increase of the reaction temperature resulted in increased yields of DEC. However, the reaction temperature higher than 140°C caused a decrease in DEC production, as expected from the reaction thermodynamics. High reaction temperature is not favorable for DEC formation via direct route from ethanol and CO2, since the reaction is exothermic. Studies on the dependence of the reaction time on the amount of DEC produced revealed that the increase of the reaction time from 2h up to 4h has not improved either DEC yield or selectivity probably due to the reaction equilibrium. The attempts of water removal from the reaction system by molecular sieves have been carried out in order to shift the equilibrium of the reaction towards DEC. Nevertheless, these attempts have failed most likely due to the high reaction temperature. The mechanism of DEC synthesis via direct route over heterogeneous catalysts has been proposed as well (Fig. 12 ). The mechanism is in accordance to the mechanism of DMC formation from CO2 and methanol over ZrO2 [79,80,106]. The oxygen atom of ethanol coordinates with unsaturated M4+ cations present on the catalyst surface to form ethoxide. Simultaneously, proton is released which reacts further with a surface hydroxyl group to form water. Subsequently, carbon dioxide is inserted into the MO and forms an ethyl carbonate group as an intermediate species which after the reaction with another molecule of ethanol forms DEC. The same reaction mechanism presented in more detail is found in reference [107]. It is also worth to mention, that the reaction chemistry in supercritical fluids (SCFs) has gained more and more attention in recent years. It is mostly since conversion and selectivity can be tuned for reactions conducted in SCFs by variations in pressure [108]. Undoubtedly, supercritical carbon dioxide due to its benign nature and relatively low critical points (P c =7.39MPa, T c =31.1°C), may be an advantageous reaction medium when acting as both as a reactant and a solvent [109]. The first attempt of DEC synthesis from ethanol and supercritical CO2 in the presence of potassium carbonate and a co-reagent, ethyl iodide, or concentrated acidic alcoholic solution has been introduced by Gasc et al. [110]. It was shown that supercritical CO2 medium considerably accelerated the rate of the DEC formation. Synthesis of diethyl carbonate from ethanol and supercritical CO2 as well as direct synthesis from ethanol and CO2 is in line with the principles of green chemistry. In both cases carbon dioxide is captured and utilized into valuable chemicals. 4 Conclusions Chemical fixation of carbon dioxide has become important from both ecological and economic viewpoints. Lately, a great number of chemical processes have been developed to convert CO2 to organic chemicals such as carbonates, lactones or carboxylic acids. In the present review different methodologies for the synthesis of short-chain dialkylcarbonates have been presented. Diethyl carbonate (DEC) is considered to be the better candidate than dimethyl carbonate (DMC) or ethanol for replacing methyl tert-butyl ether as the additive for gasoline and also an environmental benign intermediate and a raw material for industrial applications. Therefore, in this review the special emphasis has been put on diethyl carbonate synthesis methods. All the conventional production technologies raise the problems such as the toxicity of phosgene, corrosion and low production rate. Thus, the straightforward synthesis of DEC starting from cheap, easy to handle and non-toxic carbon dioxide and ethanol is recently of great importance also due to the CO2 utilization aspect. However, there exists only few reports on this topic and all of them have been summarized within this review. Moreover, it has been shown, that the direct synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2 is thermodynamically unfeasible. The introduction of butylene oxide as a chemical water trap into reaction system has remarkably enhanced the yield of DMC. The challenges for the chemists in the near future include improving the productivity by designing catalysts and developing the dehydration procedure for the direct synthesis of organic carbonates from CO2 and alcohol. coredata.dc:description: The aim of this work is to review different synthesis methods of dialkylcarbonates with special emphasis on diethyl carbonate synthesis methodologies. The novel synthesis route for dimethyl carbonate and diethyl carbonate based on the utilization of alcohol and carbon dioxide as the raw materials, together with heterogeneous catalysts, is presented.
coredata.dc:title: Conventional synthesis methods of short-chain dialkylcarbonates and novel production technology via direct route from alcohol and waste CO2
